Thus in addition to the ordinary fresh water and land shells 
and the ordinary pleistocene mammalia the musk sheep in 
these beds is associated with the Leptorhine, (Owen) and Megarhine 
Rhinoceros and <u>Elephas antiquus<\u>.  In my paper I have shown 
that the group of deposits to which this brickpit belongs is of 
an age intermediate between the Preglacial Forest bed of the 
Norfolk shore and the Postglacial river deposits, being very 
much older than the latter, basing my argument on the physical 
evidence and on the intermixture of Preglacial and Postglacial 
Mammals, on the absence of the whole group of arctic Mammals 
and especially of the Reindeer which is most abundant in 
nearly all Postglacial ossiferous deposits in England, 
and I <s>propose therefore to<\s> inserted the Lower Brickearths into 
classified Pleistocene deposits as follows. 
1. Preglacial forest bed of Norfolk, climate temperate. 
2. Lower Brickearths of Thames Valley. <s>"<\s>comparatively<s>"<\s> temperate. 
3. Glacial deposits. Climate <s>serene<\s> severe 
4. Post-glacial deposits. climate <s>serene<\s> severe but gradually becoming temperate. 
The presence of the Musk Sheep, <u>one<\u> of the arctic group of 
Mammalia is n additional link, binding the Lower Brickearths
